isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Diagnostics (1995) - ELECTRONIC CONTROL SYSTEM DIAGNOSTICS - CIRCUIT FUNCTION AND DIAGNOSTICS - BRAKE SWITCH/RELAY CIRCUITS

svcsubproc.title: SIGNAL FUNCTION
svcsubproc.para: The service brake switch circuit function is to communicate to the ECM when the service brakes are applied and when the brakes are not applied. This information is used with cruise control, PTO and engine brake operation, which are controlled by the ECM.

svcsubproc.title: Service Brake Switch(es)
svcsubproc.para: There are three configurations of switches used.

step1.para: With tractor air brakes (code 4092) a single normally open switch is used. Air pressure closes the switch with brakes applied.
With truck air brakes (4091) two normally open, air operated switches are in parallel circuits.
With hydraulic brakes (04040) two mechanical switches are used, but only one of the switches is linked to the ECM. The switches are actuated by the brake pedal arm.

svcsubproc.para: With the key ON and service brakes released, ignition voltage is applied to ECM terminal 43 and no voltage is applied to terminal 23.
When service brakes are applied, voltage is applied to ECM terminal 23 and the voltage to ECM terminal 43 is turned OFF.

svcsubproc.title: FAULT DETECTION MANAGEMENT
svcsubproc.para: The ECM continuously monitors ECM terminals 23 (BNO) and 43 (BNC). The ECM expects to see 12V at one terminal and 0 volts at the other. If the signals disagree (12 volts at both or 0 volts at both), then flash code 222 is set as an active fault.
When Flash code 222 is active, the Cruise, PTO and Engine Brake systems are disabled. If the fault is intermittent, the system does not reset until the vehicle has been shut off and restarted.
This code does not turn ON the engine warning light.

svcsubproc.title: EXTENDED DESCRIPTION
svcsubproc.para: All vehicles equipped with Cruise, PTO and/or Engine Brake utilize the Brake Switch Relay (393) to notify the ECM of a brake ON or brake OFF condition.

svcsubproc.title: WITH HYDRAULIC BRAKES
svcsubproc.para: With hydraulic brakes the system includes (2) normally open stop light switches (50) and (51) and the Brake Switch Relay (393).

svcsubproc.title: Service Brakes NOT Applied
svcsubproc.para: With the key ON and service brakes NOT APPLIED, ignition power from 10A fuse F4 (fuse H1 w/FBC) goes through the normally closed contacts (30 to 87A) of the Brake Switch Relay (393) to the ECM at terminal 43. When the brakes are not applied, the ECM sees 12 volts at terminal 43, the BNC (brake normally closed) terminal.
When the brakes are not applied, note that no voltage is present on circuit 97N to ECM terminal 23, the Brake Normally Open terminal.
When the ECM sees 12 volts at terminal 43 and 0 volts at terminal 23, it's programmed to interpret this condition as "service brakes are not applied."

svcsubproc.title: Service Brakes Applied
svcsubproc.para: Battery Power through 10A fuse F33 (fuse E3 w/FBC) is always present at the normally open (N.O.) brake switch (50). Applying the service brakes closes switch (50). With this switch closed, two things occur:

step1.para: Power is applied to the Brake Switch Relay (393) causing it to energize, opening the N.C. contacts (30 to 87A). This turns OFF the power to ECM terminal 43 (BNC). ECM terminal 43 sees 0 volts.
Power is also applied (circuit 97N) to ECM terminal 23, which is the Brake Normally Open terminal. ECM terminal 23 sees 12 volts.

svcsubproc.para: When the ECM sees 0 volts at terminal 43 and 12 volts at terminal 23, it's programmed to interpret this condition as "service brakes are applied."

svcsubproc.title: WITH AIR BRAKES
svcsubproc.para: With truck air brakes (4091), the system includes (2) normally open brake switches (70) and (71) and the Brake Switch Relay (393). With tractor air brakes (4092), the system includes (1) normally open brake switche (71) and the Brake Switch Relay (393).

svcsubproc.title: Service Brakes NOT Applied
svcsubproc.para: With the key ON and service brakes NOT APPLIED, Ignition power through 10A fuse F4 (fuse H1 w/FBC) goes through the normally closed contacts (30 to 87A) of the Brake Switch Relay (393) to ECM terminal 43. When the brakes are not applied, the ECM sees 12 volts at terminal 43, the BNC (brake normally closed) terminal.
When the brakes are not applied, note that no voltage is present on circuit 97N to ECM terminal 23, the Brake Normally Open terminal.
When the ECM sees 12 volts at terminal 43 and 0 volts at terminal 23, it's programmed to interpret this condition as "service brakes are not applied."

svcsubproc.title: Service Brakes Applied
svcsubproc.para: Battery Power through 20A fuse F9 (30A fuse D3 w/FBC) is always present at the normally open (N.O.) brake switches (70) and (71). Applying the service brakes closes switches (70) and (71). With switches (70) and/or (71) closed, two things occur:

step1.para: Power is applied to the Brake Switch Relay (393) causing it to energize, opening the N.C. contacts (30 to 87A). This turns OFF the power to ECM terminal 43 (BNC). ECM terminal 43 sees 0 volts.
Power is also applied (circuit 97N) to ECM terminal 23, which is the ECM Brake Normally Open terminal. ECM terminal 23 sees 12 volts.

svcsubproc.para: When the ECM sees 0 volts at terminal 43 and 12 volts at terminal 23, it's programmed to interpret this condition as "service brakes are applied."

svcsubproc.title: Flash Code 222
svcsubproc.para: The ECM continuously monitors ECM terminals 23 (BNO) and 43 (BNC). The ECM expects to see 12V at one terminal and 0 volts at the other. If the signals disagree (12 volts at both or 0 volts at both), then flash code 222 is set as an active fault.
When Flash code 222 is active, the Cruise, PTO and Engine Brake systems are disabled. If the fault is intermittent, the system does not reset until the vehicle has been shut off and restarted.
This code does not turn ON the engine warning light.

svcsubproc.title: Wiring Causes
svcsubproc.para: A faulty brake switch, faulty brake switch relay, open fuses and/or open or short circuits (HIGH or LOW) can cause code 222 to set.

svcsubproc.title: TROUBLESHOOTING
svcsubproc.para: The Prolink EST can be used to monitor the brake switch operation. If the monitor indicates that the brake switch is not operating properly, or code 222 is active, perform the tests in this section.

item.para: Before troubleshooting, make sure that the batteries are fully charged! Check battery cables and grounds for clean, tight connections free of damage. Voltage tests will give misleading readings if the batteries are not fully charged.

Before troubleshooting, inspect circuit connectors for pushed back, loose or damaged (spread or bent) terminals, or wires with cut strands, etc. Wires and connections must be free of damage or corrosion. When some connectors corrode, a light white residue will be present that must be removed.
Before troubleshooting, inspect the suspect circuit grounds for clean, tight connections, free of any damage.

svcsubproc.title: Bench Testing Hella Relay
svcsubproc.para:
Refer to Figure 3.24
for this test.
With relay removed from connector:

step1.para: Measure resistance between terminals 30 and 87A. If resistance is less than 2 ohms, go to step 2. If resistance is more than 2 ohms, replace the relay.
Measure resistance between terminals 30 and 87. If resistance is 100K ohms or more go to step 3. If resistance is less than 100K ohms replace the relay.
Connect (+) battery lead to terminal 85 and (-) lead to 86. The relay should energize with an audible click. If the relay energizes, go to step 4. If the relay does not energize, replace the relay.
With relay energized, measure resistance between terminals 30 and 87A. If the resistance is 100K ohms or more, go to step 5. If resistance is less than 100K ohms, replace the relay.
With relay energized, measure resistance between terminals 30 and 87. If resistance is less than 2 ohms the relay tests good. If resistance is greater than 2 ohms, replace the relay.

svcsubproc.title: PROCEDURE FOR ADJUSTING HYDRAULIC STOP LIGHT BRAKE
svcsubproc.para: Disconnect cab harness from switches. See Figure 3.25.

step1.para: With PAL nut on upper switch finger tight, connect #1 test light leads to switch. Adjust switch until light just comes ON. Note position of key/tab on connector body.
Hold PAL nut and rotate switch clockwise 1 full turn. Key/tab should be in the same position as in step 1.

note.para: The #1 test light should be off and the switch set so that the brake pedal must be moved 0.50 inches at point of contact to make the light come on.

step1.para: Tighten PAL nut on upper switch and watch key/tab so the switch is not turned when tightening the PAL nut.
With PAL nut on the lower switch finger tight, connect #2 test light leads to switch. Adjust the lower switch so that with the pedal depressed, both lights come on at the same time.

note.para: If test light #2 (lower switch) comes on first, move lower switch closer to the pedal.

step1.para: If test light #1 (upper switch) comes on first, move lower switch away from the pedal.
Tighten PAL nut on both switches and test one more time.
Remove test lights and install connector with circuits 70/70A and 70B/70C on the upper switch and connector with circuits 90A and 90B on the lower switch.
